resources.string: You have entered the temple's Inner Sanctum to see the Sleeping Man and have no further need of his Five-Fold Mysteries.
Sensei Dharvana is dead and her Five-Fold Mysteries with her. You may pursue them further but only for your own enlightenment.

Before Sensei Dharvana will let anyone enter her temple's Inner Sanctum, they must recite the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man. The Fourth-Fold Mystery is "Who did he seek?"
You have learned the Mystery from Arden Swift in the Hellbreath Tavern, who claims the Sleeping Man sought a creature called the Knower of Places.

You can feel yourself getting closer to the hidden lair of the Knower of Places. In a secret chamber deep in the icy wastes of Cania, you have found the statue of a gargoyle. Etched along its base are the words "Stone to stone the stone turns; Lightning to lightning, the lightning fades."

You have killed the Scrivener, a small dog-like beast that you found whining at the entrance to a cave at the heart of town. It seems he alone held the secret to dispelling the magical force that continues to block the cavern's entrance. It would seem the secret has died with him.

Before Sensei Dharvana will let you enter her temple's Inner Sanctum to see the Sleeping Man, she wants you to learn and recite his Five-Fold Mysteries. The Third-Fold Mystery of the Sleeping Man is "Why did he leave?"

Before Sensei Dharvana will let you enter her temple's Inner Sanctum to see the Sleeping Man, she wants you to learn and recite his Five-Fold Mysteries. The Third-Fold Mystery of the Sleeping Man is "Why did he leave?"
You learned the Mystery from the Spirits of the Dead who call the City of Lost Souls their home. They claim that the Sleeping Man's heart had known no love.

Before Sensei Dharvana will let anyone enter her temple's Inner Sanctum, they must recite the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man. The Third-Fold Mystery is "Why did he leave?"
You learned the Mystery from the Githzerai Pilgrims now trapped in Cania. They claim that the Sleeping Man's heart had known no love.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of Arden Swift, the jester you met in the Hellbreath Tavern in the City of Lost Souls. He is known in the gods' tongue as Caddisthwaite the Doomed.
Empowered by this knowledge, you recently forced him to give you all his winnings from the card tricks and gambling sessions he plays with the tavern's patrons.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of Arden Swift, the jester you met in the Hellbreath Tavern in the City of Lost Souls. He is known in the gods' tongue as Caddisthwaite the Doomed.
Empowered by this knowledge, you recently forced him to pick a fight with the tavernkeeper, a powerful Shadow Dragon.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of Arden Swift, the jester you met in the Hellbreath Tavern in the City of Lost Souls. He is known in the gods' tongue as Caddisthwaite the Doomed.
Empowered by this knowledge, you recently made him promise to write an epic song about your exploits and spread your fame throughout the planes.

Arden Swift, the jester you met in the Hellbreath Tavern in the City of Lost Souls, is now dead. It appears he ultimately lived up to his True Name: Caddisthwaite the Doomed. As a result, the name is of little use to you anymore.
Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of the Lady Aribeth de Tylmarande. She is known in the gods' tongue as Va'ardalia the Twinsouled.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of her sister, the Knower of Places. She is known in the gods' tongue as Cordemylia the Knower.

Empowered by this knowledge, you recently stopped his plans for Lordship over your homeworld of Toril which he hoped would become the Tenth Hell of Baator.

Empowered by that Knowledge, you recently woke him from his lengthy slumber.

Empowered by that Knowledge, you recently forced him to fight Sensei Dharvana, the Githzerai woman who has fashioned an entire religion around the interpretation of his dreams.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of the Sleeping Man. He is known in the gods' tongue as Celesfa'ar the Patient.
Empowered by that Knowledge, you recently commanded him to believe your lies about the identity of his one true love.

After lying so many years undisturbed, the Sleeping Man lies dead. Having paid the Knower's price, you knew his True Name to be Celesfa'ar the Patient. With his death, however, such knowledge has become useless.
After learning the identity of his one true love from the Knower of Names, you have returned to the green-skinned Sleeping Man in the City of Lost Souls and informed him of her name.

After learning that the Sensei Dharvana is the one true love of the Sleeping Man she worships, you have returned to her temple and broken the news. Her reaction was mixed and, in the end, it seems she was more comfortable worshiping the Sleeping Man than being loved by him.

After learning the identity of his one true love from the Knower of Names, you have returned to the green-skinned Sleeping Man in the City of Lost Souls. With devious intent, you have convinced him that it is someone else entirely.

After learning that the Sensei Dharvana is the one true love of the Sleeping Man she worships, you have returned to her temple to judge her reaction. With devious intent, however, you have convinced her that it is someone else, a falsehood she seems only too eager to believe.

Sensei Dharvana, the Sleeping Man's one true love, is dead. Over the course of many years they shared a closeness that few could imagine but, in the end, they never came to fully know each other as the lovers that the gods intended them to be.
The Sleeping Man is dead and with him died his lifelong quest to find his one true love.

Empowered by the knowledge of the identity of your one true love, you have pursued your ever-developing relationship with great ardor. Already you can imagine yourselves living together happily ever after...

Uncomfortable with the knowledge of the identity of your one true love, you have chosen to sabotage your still-nascent relationship. Somehow you just can't seem to come to terms with the destiny the gods have foretold for you.
Uncomfortable with the knowledge of the identity of your one true love, your heart has led you elsewhere. Somehow you just can't seem to come to terms with the destiny the gods have foretold for you.

Empowered by the knowledge of your one true love's True Name, you have taken on a more cavalier attitude of late. Seizing the opportunity such unfettered power presents, you recently commanded your lover to respond passionately to your advances and overlook the cold-hearted void that lurks within you.

Waterdeep. One of the greatest cities in all of Faerun, it is home to a multitude of peaceful folk from all races and all walks of life. Beneath Waterdeep, however, lies a different realm. This is the deep dungeon known as Undermountain, built by the mad wizard Halaster long before the city was even established above. Here Halaster tests adventurers who trespass therein with the deadliest of traps and the most dangerous of creatures. All but the luckiest meet their deaths in its dark halls. Regardless of this presence beneath them, the people of Waterdeep feel safe enough... for while one may enter Undermountain, it is rare that anything actually comes out... ...until now. For there is another realm that exists beneath even Undermountain. A place of shadows and evil known only as the Underdark. It is here that the sinister dark elves known as the Drow rule next to other subterranean horrors unknown to most on the surface world above. And it is the Drow who now lead an army of these creatures into the streets of Waterdeep, besieging the city from below in a campaign of blood and terror. And in their darkest hour, the Lords of Waterdeep have issued a call for a hero, someone who can face these dark elves and all of their brethren in their own land, someone who can defeat... ... the hordes of the Underdark.
Rogues, or other characters with high dexterity, should take the Weapon Finesse feat and use light weapons, such as short swords and daggers. They are not well suited to using strength based attacks.
The pit descends into darkness. You cannot tell how deep it is.
"The truth is what you make of it, <FirstName>. Don't get too excited yet."
"Slow down with the poetry, big boy..."
"See how he twists and squirms? You have skewered him well and good, Knower."
"Thank you, Knower. Her name is music to my ears."
"Why? Because my skin is too dark for your love!?"
"Thank you, Knower. Her name is music to my ears."
"The Knower knows of what she speaks..."
"As yours is to mine, my dear."
"Thank you, Knower. His name is music to my ears."
Remember that you can not sell items while you are shapeshifted. You need to return to your character's normal form in order to interact with stores.
You must rest before continuing your adventures.
You are permanently dead. You must load a savegame.

Use the controls on this page to pick your Editing Language. Use the Default Language unless you do any of the following:
1) You need to edit a module in a language other than the language used by your game installation. For example, you have the French version of the game, but need to edit a module for German players.
2) You are a translator who is adding translated text to a module. For example, you are editing a module that was created by an English user, and you are adding translated versions of all the text so that Italian users can play the module.
Localized text fields in the toolset have a "..." button next to them to let you edit strings for them in multiple languages.
If you do not use the "..." button and type directly in a localized text field, it will store your text in your chosen Editing Language.
If a localized text string contains text for more than one language, you will see it displayed in your Editing Language whenever possible. Otherwise, it will use the text for the next available language.
The familiar, hooded figure of the Reaper bows as you approach, enigmatic as always. Distant flames flicker within his reflective, featureless face and you shiver in spite of yourself.
"I am sorry, Sojourner," the Reaper sighs heavily. "You are now barred from the world of Toril. If you are to ask me to return you there, I cannot comply."
"I am sorry, Sojourner," the Reaper sighs heavily. "You are now barred from the world of Toril. I cannot comply."
"You are barred from returning to that world by the command of Mephistopheles." He bows low once again. "I am sorry, Sojourner. It is Mephistopheles who rules here, and so can he command me."
"The archdevil uses me as he uses all things, such is his nature. I was not always his subject... but once he learned of my True Name I was his forever."
"Not because I desired to. As I said, the archdevil commanded me with the power of my True Name."
"Nor does he need to be. As I said, the archdevil commanded me with my True Name... I cannot choose to disobey, even if he is no longer present."
"All beings have a True Name that is the definition of their personal essence, their very existence. Should another learn your True Name and speak it to you, they then rule all that you are."
"Mephistopheles discovered my True Name long ago, though I know not how. Only he knows it, so he alone commands me despite whatever I might wish."

"Mephistopheles used you, as well, creating a devil's deal that you were unaware of. A bond was formed with him the moment you discovered his relic, and upon killing the one who held him captive you took his place and he yours."
"Through your bond, you have assumed the chains that once held Mephistopheles. So as he was once bound to the realm of Cania, so now are you. His prison has become yours."

"He traded your freedom for his chains. Once he was bound to the planar realm of Cania but, through his trickery and deceit, he has escaped through the bond he formed with you. So are you now bound to Cania as he once was."

"Cania is the Eighth Hell of Baator, the Frozen Wastes and the Dreaded Depths. Here Mephistopheles is Lord of all and prisoner both... or he was, until he slipped his chains and placed them unto you."
"You forget, Sojourner... this realm is all places as well as none. We exist in Cania just as everywhere else, part of your prison just as not."

He gestures to the mist-shrouded door that stands alone at the far end of the chamber. "That path leads to Cania as it always has, as it has been a part of you since the bond was created. It is no longer barred to your passing."
"Alas, I cannot. I have been commanded by Mephistopheles not to allow you to return to Toril, and you no longer possess his relic."
"If you learned my True Name you could command me to break the bond between you and return you to Toril. I know not how you would learn of it, however, and I cannot tell it to you."
The Reaper nods solemnly. "How may I serve you, Sojourner?"
"I wish you well, Sojourner. Would that I could do more to aid you on your path."
The Reaper pauses for a moment, gazing out into the distance as if searching before finally responding. "They are dead, Sojourner. That is, however, merely a transitory state as you are well aware."
"The Spirits of the Dead can end up in many places, as their will dictates. The outer planes are infinite in their variety and who can say where a soul will go?"

"That said, this realm touches all places and so can these dead companions be found. But they will agree to come or not, each according to their desire. I cannot compel them to come here in the same way I have you. Who shall I summon?"
"The spirit refuses... I sense anger and hatred directed at you, Sojourner. He feels wronged by you and will not answer my summons. Is there anyone else you wish me to summon?"
"Consent is given. His spirit travels the gates now, hurtling towards us, and flesh is now forming... your companion returns to you."

Valen suddenly appears, as whole as the last time you saw him. He looks around, mildly bewildered. "So I am summoned from beyond the veil once again. To stand at your side, <FirstName>? I am glad to be here with you, then."

"When Mephistopheles killed me along with so many of the rebels I thought my time was done." He turns and regards the Gatekeeper. "And you, strange one... it was you I felt calling me, yes? You're the one who brought me to this... place?"
"Yes, fiendish one. <FullName> has requested your presence here in the hells... Now, Sojourner, is there anyone else you wish me to summon?"
"The spirit refuses... I sense anger and hatred directed at you, Sojourner. She feels wronged by you and will not answer my summons. Is there anyone else you wish me to summon?"
"Consent is given. Her spirit travels the gates now, hurtling towards us, and flesh is now forming... your companion returns to you."
Nathyrra suddenly appears, looking startled. She draws one of her daggers almost without thinking. "What... where am I?" Her eyes focus on you. "<FirstName>? So I am... alive once more."

Slowly she nods, comprehension coming to her. "Thank you for bringing me back, then, my friend. To have died at Mephistopheles's hand along with so many others was unsettling, to say the least." She looks around. "And what is this place? Are we in the planes?"
"Yes, dark one. <FullName> has requested your presence here in the hells... Now, Sojourner, is there anyone else you wish me to summon?"
"Consent is given. His spirit travels the gates now, hurtling towards us, and flesh is now forming... your companion returns to you."

Deekin suddenly appears. Strangely, he does not seem surprised nor disturbed by his situation. "There you is, boss! Deekin keeps telling angels that he gots lots to do, that he not stayings up there, but they not believes him!"

<StartAction>(sigh)</Start> "Deekin be right all along, just like Deekin says. Stupid angels." He looks around a bit, taking in the chamber. "Ummm... is we in hell, boss? Place needs good cleaning, maybe."
"Yes, little one. <FullName> has requested your presence here in the hells... Now, Sojourner, is there anyone else you wish me to summon?"
The Reaper nods slowly. "The Sleeping Man is wise and old. He passed through the Gates of Cania when they were first formed, long before the time of my creation."
"It has been many ages since I saw him last, yet I suspect he remains there even still, asleep and waiting. Is this so?"
"Carved about the dais where he sleeps were once the words 'She will find you by the Gates of Cania.' And thus he waits for her."
"Death or a maiden fair, who can say? The words are there, in answer to a question he must have once asked. That is all I know."

"You have learned my True Name, I see... Very well, I have summoned a door that will return you to the one you know as Durnan, in Waterdeep. But, before you go, is there anything else you would have me do?"
"A word of warning before you go, Sojourner... By breaking the chains Mephistopheles placed upon you and stepping through that door, you forfeit the bond that brought you to this place."
"You will not see me again nor lay your eyes upon the ice of Cania." The Reaper bows deeply. "It has been a... pleasure to serve you. I wish you well, Sojourner."
"Consider the Devils of Cania unleashed, m'<Lord/Lady>, but once set loose upon the mortal realm, they will not be easy to rein back in. Even so, I shall comply. Anything more?"
"If that is your wish, I shall make it so. Even death itself will no longer hold the spirits here. Is there anything else you would ask of me?"
"As you command, Sojourner. I will return them safely to their home in Limbo. Is there anything else?"
"Your destination lies here in Cania, thus may I comply... Behold, a Gate has been opened unto you, leading to the place where you last died."

"Only what I have already spoken to you. Cania is the Eighth Hell of Baator, a frigid land where Mephistopheles once ruled. It is a plane of torment and evil... be wary should you step unto its icy shores."
"There was a time when I roamed free, and I knew much of the Cania that was. I know little of the frozen waste that exists now, however, and I have no power there. I cannot help you."

"Remember that you are now bound to Cania. If you knew my True Name, I could break that bond and send you from here. Otherwise even if you were to find another portal I would only retrieve you once more."
"I cannot openly betray the one who holds my True Name, Sojourner." There is almost the hint of a smile in the Reaper's featureless mirror of a face.
"Abuse it more than the archdevil himself already has?" The Reaper shakes his head slowly. "I think not."
"This I do not know. I cannot provide it to you willingly, Sojourner... and I have no knowledge of how Mephistopheles discovered it. If you did learn it, however, then would you be free."
He shakes his head. "I know of none. If any exist, they are well beyond your reach. It would be far easier for you to seek my True Name... though even that is a near impossible task."
"You have great power, Sojourner, but I am a part of this realm that is everywhere and nowhere. You could only destroy me if you possessed the power to destroy me in all places... which you do not."
The familiar, hooded figure of the Reaper bows as you approach, enigmatic as always. Distant flames flicker within his reflective, featureless face and you shiver in spite of yourself.

You have not visited this realm often since acquiring the Relic of the Reaper, but whenever you have it is always the same... the dire chill in the air seeps through to your bones, and the hum of ancient magic is all around you.
The familiar, hooded figure of the Reaper bows as you approach, enigmatic as always. Distant flames flicker within his reflective, featureless face and you shiver in spite of yourself.
The Reaper nods solemnly. "How may I serve you, Sojourner?"
"Much time has passed since last you walked within this hall, Sojourner. Perhaps this is indeed the moment to remind you of the nature of the relic you carry."

The Reaper gestures to the small artifact. "The relic is bound to you, and you to it. It is your key to this nexus realm, and you may use it to come here willingly... or be brought here at the moment prior to your death."
"This is a nexus realm, Sojourner, a place that touches everywhere and yet nowhere."
"If you were brought here to avoid your mortal death, the energy used by the rogue stone will allow me to mark that place and return you there if you wish. You need only ask."
The Reaper gestures to the doors behind him. "The central portal is always anchored to your realm, though it may not bring you where you wish to go. The other portals must be anchored to be used."
"The gems contain a power that, when consumed, can be felt even from the furthest planes. Think of it as a point of reference, Sojourner, that allows this plane to touch yours."

"If you are on your home plane and you possess a rogue stone, you may use its energy to anchor one of this plane's portals to that spot. After that point, you may use that door to return to that spot at will."
"That is a forbidden portal for you, Sojourner, for you yet have life within you."
"It is not yet time for you. Use the other portals here and be thankful."
"The location moves, from time to time. Always it is tied to somewhere you have been, Sojourner, as this realm is tied to you through the relic."
"Nay, Sojourner. In order for the relic to transport you here so quickly so as to avoid your death, it requires great energy... energy it can only draw from a rogue stone."
"So long as you carry such a stone in your possession you are indeed safe. Should you not have one, however, you will perish... as all mortals do."
"As you wish. How else may I serve you, Sojourner?"
"As you wish, Sojourner. Should you have need of me, here I shall remain."
"Behold, Sojourner... A Gate has been opened unto you that you might join with the leader of your fellows."
"Behold, Sojourner... A Gate has been opened unto you, leading to the place where you last died."
"I am bound to it, Sojourner, as it is bound to you."
"It is, however, the only answer that I can give." The Reaper bows low, sounding almost apologetic. "The relic is what it is, just as you are. Better to ask who created you, Sojourner."
"This is the Gatehouse, an entry point into the Land of the Dead," he gestures all about him. "You are welcome here but I do not recommend you linger."
"I know of none, for it is not my place to know such things. I am part of this realm, and it is all of my concern."
"That is not for you, Sojourner," he interrupts. "Seek it not, for it is not yet your time to pass through it."
"As I have already spoken, it is not yet your time. I can say no more."
"Have you forgotten already, Sojourner? If you wish, I can speak of the relic you carry and its relation to the nexus realm."
"Than what else would you ask of this realm?"
"As I have already reminded you, they are points that may be anchored to your plane. Until then, they drift free and lead nowhere but here."
"It is nowhere, and yet everywhere. This is a nexus realm, Sojourner, that is tied to you... it touches on all places that you were, are and will be."
"Understanding is not required. The only requirement is that you carry the relic with you. Therefore the nexus is yours."
"You have asked me this many times, Sojourner, and yet I give you the only answer I can: I am the Reaper, the Gatherer of Dust, the Gatekeeper... and this is my realm."
"I rule this place only so far as any being can rule themselves. We are the same, this realm and I. I am King but never master."
The Reaper's reflective face reveals no emotion, yet he pauses. "You hold the Relic of the Reaper, Sojourner. Therefore you rule here... for now."
"I am bound to it as it is bound to you. So long as you hold it, you command this place... and therefore you command me."
"I cannot leave this place, Sojourner, for I am this place. As I am tied to the relic you carry, so do I already journey with you always."
"I am not a slave, nor am I prisoner. A place can be a prison, but cannot itself be imprisoned... though it can be commanded. Remember that."
"I have always been here. As this nexus realm was created, so was I created with it. We are the same, one an extension of the other."
"I could give you the answer to your question, Sojourner, but it would mean nothing to you. Those who created us are passed out of knowing."
"I am a being of the planes, Sojourner... no more, no less." You think there is almost a hint of a smile in the Reaper's blank features.
"Surely. And yet not a one of them is my True Name."
"All beings have a True Name, Sojourner. Even you. It defines the essence of your being and gives you power over your actions. Always it must remain secret."
"To surrender your True Name is to surrender your power, your very essence, to another. Be glad that as a mortal you are unaware of it and thus may never surrender it."

"You have not truly perished," the figure reminds you, "as the relic will always pull you to this realm at the very moment of your death. From here," he gestures to the doors behind him, "you may return to whence you came."
The Reaper's emotionless face gleams at you from the darkness. It seems he has nothing left to say to you.
"I have died and wish to return to where I fell."
"You can't comply? But I command you!"
"What? Who says I'm barred from there?"
"So you worked for Mephistopheles all along."
"I knew it! You lied to me!"
"But he's not here to command you now."
"What do you mean he took my place?"
"Cania? Isn't that one of the Nine Hells?"
"The realm of Cania? What do you mean?"
"Here? But... I'm not in Cania, am I?"
"Is there nothing you can do to help me?"
"What of my companions? Where are they?"
"I seek the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man."
"Yes, it is. What is he waiting for?"
"So tell me again what I could do to return home?"
"Hecugoth the Abandoned, I command you to grant me passage home!"
"Thank you, Reaper. That will be all."
"Allow the Devils to wreak their havoc on the planes."
"Allow the Spirits of the Dead to haunt the Living."
"Allow the Githzerai Pilgrims to return home."
"I have died and wish to return to where I fell."
"Surely there are other ways back to Toril?"
"You sound as if you'd prefer to betray Mephistopheles."
"But aren't you worried that I might abuse your True Name?"
"How could I discover your True Name?"
"I should destroy you for betraying me."
"It is good to see you again, Reaper."
"I would like to know more about how the Relic works."
"How do I return home from here?"
"What about the far door, the one covered in mist?"
"You have to be dead to go through it?"
"So I am immortal? I cannot die?"
"I must go to the leader of my adventuring party."
"I have died and wish to return to where I fell."
"But who created the relic? What is it?"
"Tell me about your realm once again."
"There is a door at the far end of the room, covered in mist..."
"I would like to know more about you."
"Do you rule here? Or do you serve another?"
"What is the significance of the relic?"
"So could I command you to come with me?"
"Is there no way to free you?"
"How did you come to be here?"

This blade is almost as nasty as the personality that now permanently resides within it. With each hit, it draws a little bit of the life-force inside and uses some of it to heal the wielder. Whether it could potentially draw more of that life-force, or has other side effects, is unknown... even to Enserric himself. The long-dead mage has been within the weapon for quite a while but has not gotten much use, seeing as for decades the primary user was even deader than Enserric. ...hmmm. Deader? More dead? Can something be more dead? This is exactly the sort of question that makes Enserric clam up and begin muttering in pure agitation...
"I guess I could answer a few questions for you. Can't see any harm in it. Besides, it's not like the Maker's golems here on the island will tell you anything." She smiles briefly at her own joke.
"Well, the island was named after the ancient duergar mage who built his stronghold here centuries ago. They say the Maker came here so he could work in peace while perfecting his golems."
"There must be some truth to these stories. There's some ruins to the north that could have been the Maker's laboratory, though all that's left is the dungeon. And there's the golems, of course."
"The dungeon at the north end of the island is crawling with golems. At least, the first floor of it is. We don't go any deeper. We figure they're guardians left over from the Maker. "
"They must have been built to protect against thieves and scavengers." She gives you a rueful look. "They do a pretty good job, too. We've lost more than a few duergar during our expeditions."
She shakes her head. "Not possible. There's some kind of scavenger golem in there that repairs and rebuilds any golems we manage to take down."
"We've tried to kill the scavenger, but it's got a number of magical defenses. Every time we attack it, it teleports away to safety. That damn thing makes our job a lot tougher."
"Everything I know about the Maker comes from legends and myths. They say he was a powerful duergar sorcerer who isolated himself on this island to work on his research."
"His specialty was crafting golems. According to the legends, he found a way to imbue his constructs with intelligence and free will. But the golems we've run into seem pretty standard to me."
"Nobody really knows; he disappeared five centuries ago. Most people think he was killed off by his own creations: intelligent golems with a will of their own."
"I don't know if I really believe that, but it makes a good story. The only golems we've run across in the dungeon don't seem all that smart to me. Damn tough to kill, though."
This duergar female looks you up and down, gauging your strength and trying to judge if you are a threat. Satisfied that you pose no immediate harm, she seems to relax slightly.
The duergar raise their weapons, but at a signal from their leader they hold their ground. She gives you a quick once over, evaluating you as a potential threat.
"If this is a joke, you picked the wrong group to play games with. We're not looking for a fight, but we're well armed and we will defend ourselves."
"You should've picked an easier target! Attack!"
She nods. "Fair enough. As long as you aren't here to cause trouble for us, you can keep your secrets. My name is Dahanna. I'm the leader of this expedition."
The duergar visibly relaxes, though she is still studying you carefully as she addresses you once more. "My name is Dahanna. I'm the leader of this expedition."
"Come and go as you please, surfacer. You don't answer to us."
She nods thoughtfully. "The Valsharess. I've heard about her. One of the drow matron mothers, isn't she? She's made quite a name for herself recently."
"I hear she's been attacking the surface... I guess that's why you're looking to stop her. But you won't find any help against her here. If the drow don't bother us, we don't bother them."
<StartCheck>Failure</Start> Dahanna shakes her head slowly. "I don't want trouble with you, surfacer. But you bullying us won't make us join you. Our minds are set; you can't change them."
<StartCheck>Failure</Start> Dahanna shrugs. "Maybe. But the Valsharess isn't the first drow we've seen rise to power. Most of them get toppled long before they ever turn their attention to us."
"We're treasure hunters. Centuries ago, this island was home to a powerful duergar wizard known as the Maker, or so the stories go. The Maker's long gone, but he left a few things behind."
"We come out here to salvage rare metal and pieces of golems from the ruins of the Maker's tower. You'd be surprised what the right buyer will pay for an arm made of pure adamantine."
She grins. "But it isn't easy. Not too many expeditions come here anymore. There's still some good metal to be found, but you have to be willing to go toe-to-toe with the Maker's golems."
"As usual, the duergar are scavengers, living off the scraps of others."
"Better watch your tongue, drow! This is duergar territory. Your arrogance might have cost you more than you're willing to pay."
Dahanna and the other duergar approach you. You notice their weapons are drawn and that they have packed up their camp. Dahanna appears uncomfortable, as if she is ashamed of what is about to happen.
<StartAction>Failure</Start> Dahanna smiles. "You're <race> lies don't fool me. You were in there far too long to come out empty handed. Now, give us what's rightfully ours."
<StartAction>Success</Start> Dahanna cocks her head to the side, considering your words. "You seem sincere. I can't say for sure whether you're lying or not," she finally admits.
There's some angry grumbling from the other soldiers, but she cuts them off with a sharp gesture. "I'm not going to let this come to bloodshed only to find out we were fighting over nothing."
<StartAction>Failure</Start> "We've held our own against the Maker's golems. I think we can manage against a <race> surfacer like you. We'll fight for what is rightfully ours."
<StartAction>Success</Start> Dahanna studies you closely, then seems to come to a decision. "You're probably right, surfacer. We're not willing to throw our lives away."
"You've gone deeper into the Maker's dungeon than we ever did, and you've come back to tell the tale. We'd be foolish to go up against you, even as desperate as we are."
<StartAction>Failure</Start> "We've been working this island for twenty years, and we've lost our fair share of duergar. We've paid our dues... you owe us something!"

<StartAction>Success</Start> "Maybe... maybe you're right, surfacer. We aren't thieves, we earn our living honestly." There is some angry grumbling from the soldiers, but Dahanna cuts them off with a single gesture.
The leader of the duergar shakes her head. "I'm sorry for this. But we count on these expeditions to survive. Each time we come back, we find less and less good metal. We are growing desperate."
Dahanna looks at you with obvious disbelief, though she takes the offered coins. "You would do this for us, after what just happened? You are more forgiving than we duergar, surfacer."
She smiles. "Thank you for this gift. Our expedition here is over now, we're heading back to our homes and our families. It will be nice to return with a few extra coins."
"Our expedition here is over now, surfacer. We're heading back to our homes and our families."
"I can't honestly say whether we will come back to this island again. In any case, we wish you luck, surfacer. Remember: the Underdark is a dangerous place."
She nods. "Maybe you're right. Perhaps the rewards here are no longer worth the risks. There are other places we can go, places far less dangerous than this island."
<StartAction>Failure</Start> Dahanna considers your counter offer carefully, calculating the chances of her group against you. Finally she shakes her head.
"One thousand gold won't go very far, split between all of us. I think we've earned the right to at least 10,000, considering you're poaching our claim here."
Dahanna sighs. "I was hoping it wouldn't come to this, but I can see you aren't being reasonable. Attack!"
<StartAction>Success</Start> Dahanna considers your counter offer carefully, calculating the chances of her group against you. Finally, she nods in acceptance.
The soldiers behind Dahanna begin to murmur excitedly, but she cuts them off with a sharp hand gesture. She takes the offered coins and says, "I'm glad this was done without bloodshed."
"A polite thief is still a thief. Being courteous doesn't make this right."
"Well, at least you is polite... for a thief."
"Well, at least you're being courteous while you rob us. That's more than I expected from your kind."
Nathyrra spits on the ground. "You would bargain with this hargluk?"
Dahanna ignores her. "If you give us 10,000 gold pieces, we'll let you go on your way without any trouble. If not, we'll take what's rightfully ours by force."
"Nothing personal? That's funny. When a pack of armed thugs points their weapons at me, I tend to take it *very* personally."
"Look, Boss! Them duergar is coming to give us a welcome back surprise party... uh, wait. Deekin not thinks this a party after all. Too bad. Deekin wants cake."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"I would've thought you'd cleared all the golems out by now."
"Friend or foe? Uh... I guess I'll pick foe!"
"It's no joke. I just want to slaughter you all. I'm funny that way."
"Calm down. I'm not looking for a fight, either."
"My name and business are my own."
"My name is <FullName>. I don't mean any harm."
"Time for this to get bloody. Die, you Underdark excuse for a dwarf!"
"I'm looking for allies to help me against the Valsharess."
<StartCheck>Persuade: Intimidate</Start> "You're either with me or against me. Think about it."
"I gave you a chance. Now you'll pay the price!" <StartAction>Attack.</Start>
"Fine. I want to ask you something else then."
<StartCheck>Persuade</Start> "Eventually the Valsharess will turn her army against the duergar, too."
"Settle down. We just want to ask you some questions."
"Nobody threatens me! Death to the duergar!" <StartAction>Attack.</Start>
"Is this some kind of shake down?"
"Your island? What are you talking about?"
"I think I see where this is going..."
"Maybe we could work out a deal."
<StartAction>Persuade:Bluff</Start> "I didn't find anything worthwhile. You've picked this place clean."
<StartAction>Persuade: Intimidate</Start> "Careful now. This may be more than you can handle."
<StartAction>Persuade</Start> "You have no right to my stuff. I did all the work!"
"Apology *not* accepted! You'll pay for this with blood!"
"Sounds like times are tough. Here's a thousand gold to help you out."
"Maybe it's time you moved on to somewhere else."
<StartAction>Persuade</Start> "I'll give you a thousand gold... no more."

This vile staff was wielded by Sodalis, the fearsome High Priest of Vix'thra who ruled over the free-village of Drearing's Deep in the Underdark. The swirling vortex at the staff's tip is said to be a god's-eye view of the infinite layers of the Abyss.

Rumor has it that Deathslayer was originally crafted for use by an assassin sent to eliminate a powerful lich. His fate is still unknown, but it's doubtful he would have willingly abandoned this blade.
Originally wielded by an unknown gnomish hero who single-handedly wiped out the evil wizard Tnert's legions of golems, this blade's whereabouts have become the subject of tavern gossip.
You've purchased a female thrall from the illithid and sent her off to the fighting pits - a truly grim fate. At least you'll be able to wager on her battles... until she dies.
You've purchased a female thrall from the illithid. However, once free from their mind controlling powers she attacked you. Obviously, she would rather die than live her life in servitude.

You've come up with a plan to gain the freedom of the female thrall you purchased from the illithid. Because of the mind flayers' telepathic abilities, you can't reveal your plan to her.
You've sent her to deliver a fake message to the Seer. Since she believes she is magically bound to you, the illithid will consider her a thrall in your service and allow her to leave their city. Once back at the rebel camp, you can explain the truth to her.
You've purchased a female thrall from the illithid and sent her off to the fighting pits - she fought bravely but died as a gladiator.

The thrall you freed from the illithid managed to find her way back to the Seer's camp. Once the threat of the Valsharess is no more, the Seer has promised to help her find her way back to the surface so she can leave the Underdark behind her forever.
The female thrall from the illithid slave market has been killed.

You've freed a group of thralls from the pens of Zorvak'Mur. Though eager for freedom, you've convinced them to wait until you reach the Elder Brain before they begin their revolt. However, you know that if their rebellion succeeds, any chance of convincing the illithid to abandon the Valsharess is likely gone.

You've freed a group of thralls from the pens of Zorvak'Mur. Under their leader, Argosus, they've launched a bid for freedom. The only downside is that you've likely destroyed any chance you had of convincing the illithid to abandon the Valsharess.

You've betrayed Argosus and his followers in order to garner the goodwill of the Zorvak'Mur Overmind. No doubt the thralls will suffer terribly for their attempted escape, but it's a price you're willing to pay.

You've freed a group of thralls from the pens of Zorvak'Mur, and they plan to start a rebellion once you've reached the Elder Brain. Should their revolt succeed, you likely won't have any chance of gaining the support of Zorvak'Mur or the illithid in your cause.

You've betrayed the thrall rebellion for the sake of the greater good. By denying Argosus and his followers their freedom, you still have a chance to convince the Zorvak'Mur Elder Brain to help you against the Valsharess.

"...As wise and powerful as you are, Eye Tyrant Arutha, your lack of progress on the matters we have agreed to angers me. You promised me at least a dozen beholders to help attack the rebellious drow. What I have seen from you thus far is only two beholders! I am sending some of my slaves with this letter to escort the remaining beholders. Satisfy me and I may not bind you to spend the rest of eternity in the dark. Exceed my expectations and I will give you their weight in gold as well. Disappoint me, however, and I will destroy even the memory of your pathetic little hive. The choice is yours..."
"Talk all you want, berk. Gru'ul declared a holiday so I've got the time."

"Honor? Honor!? Honor, my great-aunt Ninny's soggy bum it's honor! This here is punishment, berk! If the Big M had wanted to honor me, he wouldn't have put me in charge of this lot of boot-licking incompetents!"
"He named you Quarry Boss? That must be quite the honor..."
"It hurts to use them, I'll have you know. 'Tis a good thing I take pleasure in my own suffering. What aspect of my former self would you have me tap?"
"Yes, let us play at being good no more..."
"I want you to use one of your special abilities."
"Time seems different in the cold... Memory... seems different... All I know is that we chose this place, somehow... Welcome to the Eighth Hell of Baator, I suppose..."
"No! I will not believe it! You are but a devil sent to tempt me! If you wish me to believe it, you must bring me proof. All else is falsehood!"
"Did I say yes? I meant no."
"I saw her corpse in the other room."
"In the passing of seven spokes a hole was dug and a fearsome devil freed. Had the digging been done but sixteen spokes the sooner, it would have uncovered what you need."
"I am an ancient baatorian, Planetar. With every answer, I become more like the question."

Deekin looks at you with big, soulful eyes. "You... you would miss me, boss? Then... then Deekin not goings to betray you!" He suddenly turns on Mephistopheles. "You may be bigger than the boss, BUT DEEKIN NOT LIKES YOU!!"
"My love will go where it wishes, devil. All the promises you could make are nothing next to all this woman here can offer me. Consider your offer refused."
Valen glares at the archdevil. "It would not be worth betraying my love for <FirstName>, that is sure. If there is a taint to be removed today, it is yours, devil!"

"But I embrace that killer in you, Nathyrra... Set aside your guilt! Be true to yourself! You are a Red Sister. Join with me, Nathyrra. As a Red Sister, who would you rather serve? <FullName> or myself...?"
Nathyrra ponders his words for a long moment, then smiles sadly at him. "I would rather serve the one I love. I may still be a killer but let it be you I kill today, Mephistopheles."
The battle still rages on the far bank. If you have plans for this catapult, they will have to wait.
Frost clings to this spirit's form. Her eyes bear a commanding gaze.
The tall, grey-skinned woman appears calm before you, her countenance somber. Muscles ripple beneath her leathery skin.
There is a dark malevolence to your newfound ally and a tension in the air when you're around her.
There is a righteous vigor to Aribeth's ghostly form and her former reticence seems barely a memory.
Though her impressive wings flutter, the Knower of Places makes no breeze. You wonder if she was born in this form or has somehow chosen it along the way.
Worn by devout githzerai, these woven strappings are adorned with passages from various religious texts that they hold dear.

This hastily scrawled note bears Mephistopheles' now-familiar script:
"I am about to make my move and lay claim to Toril. Perhaps the Tanar'ri have caught wind of this for I have just received word that they are launching an assault near where I have stationed you. Stray catapult fire from the battle has already melted through the ice and freed one of my treacherous generals. Make your way to the prison and fend the Tanar'ri off at all costs. The last thing I need is some fool demon getting his paws on my Knower of Names. Serve me well and I may give you lordship over Waterdeep once it is mine..."
It appears that this particular front of the Blood War was opened just before he left for your homeworld, Toril.

In speaking with the Spirits of the Dead who cluster around the Gates of Cania, you have learned that they had a leader who had stood up to Mephistopheles when he first announced that he would be devouring their souls to fuel his undead army in your homeworld of Toril. He must have done something dire to her, however, for after the confrontation, she fled to a cave in the center of the city where she now refuses to speak with anyone. The Spirits say she's becoming one of the Lost, those who have given up hope and are slowly merging with the icy essence of Cania.

You have rescued Aribeth de Tylmarande, the ghostly leader of the Spirits of the Dead, from the icy grip of Cania. Thanks to your efforts and persistence, she has dedicated what remains of this threadbare afterlife to the cause of evil. With that, you have restored her to her former status as a fearsome Blackguard and she has offered to aid you in your quest through the Hells.

Trapped here much like you, a group of githzerai Pilgrims have related an interesting tale regarding a certain fellow named Arden Swift who has been traveling with them for the past while. According to the prevailing gossip, Arden got into an argument with the Pilgrims' leader regarding his sacriligious plans to wake the so-called Sleeping Man who the Pilgrims are here to visit. Arden's currently drowning his sorrows in the Hellbreath Tavern in the city's southeast corner.

You have met a jester, Arden Swift, in the Hellbreath Tavern in the city's southeast corner. He seems somehow associated with the githzerai Pilgrims currently patronizing the establishment but, given his tiefling heritage and the dirty looks they occasionally slip him over their half-empty tankards, you're unsure how.

In talking with Arden Swift, a bard traveling with the githzerai, he has told you of his rather sacriligious plans to wake their so-called Sleeping Man using a Trumpet of Pandemonium he acquired somewhere in his travels. Due to a quick intervention on the part of the Pilgrims' sensei, the jester's plan never came to pass but he still carries the trumpet and it might be possible to convince him to part with it.

Arden Swift, patron of the Hellbreath Tavern and itinerant jester currently taveling with the entourage of githzerai Pilgrims, has placed his beloved Trumpet of Pandemonium as a prize for an upcoming card game. He had intended to use the trumpet to wake the so-called Sleeping Man but had been caught red-handed by the Pilgrims' sensei before he could sound its blast. If you're interested in acquiring it for yourself, you merely have to place your ante on the table and guess the card he's holding in five questions or less. You're not entirely sure if you can trust him but it might be worth a try.

The familiar blackness of death enveloped you but the blood-red eyes of your betrayer, Mephistopheles, lingered to the end. And then you woke to find your eyes reflected in the Reaper's shimmering skin. Everything seems strangely familiar...

The archdevil Mephistopheles has played you for a fool. He has commanded your mysterious ally, the Reaper, to bar your return to Waterdeep in your homeworld of Toril, trapping you instead in some hellish world called Cania. The Reaper seems sympathetic to your plight but claims he has no choice but to obey for Mephistopheles has commanded him by his True Name. Such names seem to have a strange power in this place and it seems the only way to break Mephistopheles' prohibition will be learn the Reaper's True Name for yourself.

Your search for the Reaper's True Name has turned up its first clue: one of the citizens of this strange city claims that an old and venerable creature known as the Sleeping Man might have the information your looking for. He sleeps in the city's northwest quarter and apparently has done so for longer than anyone can remember. Hopefully, with his help, you'll be able to return home to Waterdeep and take your vengeance on the archdevil Mephistopheles.

The Sleeping Man was not as helpful in your quest for the Reaper's True Name as you had hoped. You did learn, however, of an ancient race called the Knowers that populated Cania before it was colonized by the legions of hell. One of them, the Knower of Names, was banished by Mephistopheles to an unknown prison deep in Cania's frozen wastelands. Unable to find the Knower of Names, the Sleeping Man instead sought out her sister, the Knower of Places, with the help of a magical ring that that served as his guide through Cania's wastes. If you can repeat his feat, perhaps she will be able to help you find her sister's hidden prison. The Sleeping Man broke the ring into three parts and hid it in a guarded vault below his chambers. It seems your journey will begin there.

The Sleeping Man's ring that will lead you to the Knower of Places and hopefully to the Reaper's True Name is a strange artifact indeed. When you slip it onto your finger, it is as if you can see into another sort of space, another dimension. Some things are present there that are not present in the real world and some things you would expect to find have disappeared. According to the Sleeping Man, the ring will be most helpful in the out of doors where a line of glowing arrows will apparently chart a safe course for you through Cania's vast wastelands. You feel the stirrings of hope in your chest for the first time since Mephistopheles banished you to this frozen place.

Tormented by her loneliness, the Knower of Places has agreed to help you on your quest for the Reaper's True Name. She has woven a new magic into the Sleeping Man's ring, allowing it to guide you to her sister, the Knower of Names, just as it guided you to her. She left you with a cryptic parting message that will hopefully aid you when you reach her sister's icy prison: "Time is a twelve-spoked wheel and with every hour of our lives another spoke has come and gone. In the passing of seven spokes a hole was dug and a fearsome devil freed. Had the digging been done but sixteen spokes the sooner, it would have uncovered what you need." Hopefully you'll be able to compel the Reaper to return you to Waterdeep before Mephistopheles has destroyed your home forever.

At long last you have learned the True Name of the Reaper: Hecugoth the Abandoned. You say it aloud a few times, rolling it around on your tongue. It has a sad sound to it but you are eager to put it to use. It's your ticket out of here, back to Waterdeep and your homeworld of Toril... or whatever still remains of them after the chaos that Mephistopheles has sown in your absence. The Knower of Names will take you back to the Gates of Cania but you pause to consider whether you have any pressing tasks you wish to accomplish on this plane before you go. Facing Mephistopheles won't be easy and you'd better have made your peace with the world.

Commanded by his True Name, the Reaper has opened a Planar Gate that will lead you back home to Waterdeep. Mephistopheles won't be expecting you so you'll have to take advantage of whatever element of surprise you have. It will pay to be well-prepared before you step through that gate.

Peering into an ice crystal that thrust itself up from Cania's glacial floor, you saw a vision of Mephistopheles' progress in your homeworld of Toril. It appears that he has discovered the carnage you left behind at the Rebel Camp. As he passed through the rotting carcasses, they rose in his wake, a ghostly army bound to do his bidding...

A group of disconsolate Pilgrims are trapped in Cania much like you. Their leader, the sensei, led them here to worship at the feet of a figure they refer to as the Sleeping Man. She can be found in the Temple in the city's northwest corner.

Dharvana, the githzerai sensei, insists that you must learn and recite the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man before she will let you into the temple's Inner Sanctum to see him. She listed the Five-Fold Mysteries as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?

Before you may enter the Temple of the Sleeping Man's Inner Sanctum, you must learn the Five-Fold Mysteries and recite them to Dharvana, the githzerai sensei. The Five-Fold Mysteries are as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?
You have learned the answer to one of those five Mysteries.

Dharvana, the githzerai sensei, insists that you must learn and recite the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man before she will let you into the temple's Inner Sanctum to see him. She listed the Five-Fold Mysteries as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?
You have now learned the answer to two of those five Mysteries.

Dharvana, the githzerai sensei, insists that you must learn and recite the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man before she will let you into the temple's Inner Sanctum to see him. She listed the Five-Fold Mysteries as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?
You have now learned the answer to three of those five Mysteries.

Dharvana, the githzerai sensei, insists that you must learn and recite the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man before she will let you into the temple's Inner Sanctum to see him. She listed the Five-Fold Mysteries as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?
You have now learned the answer to four of those five Mysteries.

Dharvana, the githzerai sensei, insists that you must learn and recite the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man before she will let you into the temple's Inner Sanctum to see him. She listed the Five-Fold Mysteries as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?
You have now learned the answer to all five of those Mysteries, should you wish to recite them before the Sensei.

There, in the temple's Inner Sanctum, with the winged form of the Sleeping Man prostrate before you, you tried in vain to make use of the sensei's amulet. The crystal glowed a murky green when in his presence and you could feel its growing hum but you somehow lacked the wisdom to tap into its psionic powers.

There, in the temple's Inner Sanctum, with the winged form of the Sleeping Man prostrate before you, you made use of the sensei's amulet. The crystal glowed a murky green when in his presence and you could feel its growing hum and then, all at once, you found yourself swept up within his dreams.

There, in the temple's dim green light, the sensei's amulet clasped about your neck, you dreamed the dreams of the Sleeping Man. Mephistopheles was there and a woman called the Knower of Names, whom he banished. And an older woman, the Knower of Places, whom the Sleeping Man had visited in search of his one true love. Throughout his quest, he was somehow guided by a ring that now lies, buried and guarded, in a chamber below him. If you hope to find the Knowers, you will need that ring upon your finger...
There, in the temple's dim green light, you have done the unthinkable and woken the Sleeping Man. Hopefully he will be able to tell you the Reaper's True Name.

In waking the Sleeping Man, you unleashed the sensei's fury. Driven mad with rage, she attacked and you had no choice but to defend yourself. Now she lies dead at the feet of the Sleeping Man who she worshiped. You decide you should keep her amulet as something to remember her by.

The Sleeping Man knows many things but, sadly, the Reaper's True Name is not one of them. Even so, he tells of a race of creatures called the Knowers who once called Cania home. One of them, the Knower of Names was banished by Mephistopheles long ago while the other, the Knower of Places, lives in hiding deep in Cania's frozen wastelands. His own quest had brought him the latter's hidden lair, long ago, a feat made possible only with the aid of an enchanted ring. The ring lies in a chamber under the temple, guarded and kept safe all these many years. He has invited you to make use of the ring, provided you can claim it, and wishes you well on your journey.

Mephistopheles left five Guardians to block the Sleeping Man's path. The two weakest were defeated in ages past and a third and fourth killed recently by your hands. You have now killed the fifth and final guardian, a wizardly Pit Fiend who stood guard over the prison itself, perhaps there to protect it from the Blood War that raged so close at hand. With all five Guardians dead, the Knower of Names is yours and her secrets too. Now if only you can find some way to free her from the ice.

You can feel yourself getting closer to the hidden lair of the Knower of Places. In a secret chamber deep in the icy wastes of Cania, you have found the statue of a gargoyle. Etched along its base in blue lettering are the words "Stone to stone, the stone turns. Lightning to lightning, the lightning fades."

A series of chambers run deep beneath the ice of Cania, leading to what you hope will be the hidden lair of the Knower of Places. Various obstacles have stood in your way but now a portal has appeared, leading into a third chamber that lies beyond.

As you peer at the sensei's amulet, you notice that the light seems to play strangely off its crystalline structure. Not quite sure what to make of this strange behavior, you return it to your pack for later investigation.

In a fortunate twist of fate, the sensei's amulet has revealed its true nature. By carefully controlling the angle at which the light strikes its crystalline structure, you find that the resulting refraction has the unexpected ability to modify your body's form. You file the knowledge away for future reference. From here on in, you decide to be more a little more mindful of your magic items, that they don't trigger again so unexpectedly.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of the Reaper of Cania and can finally command him to send you home to the Prime Material. He is known in the gods' tongue as Hecugoth the Abandoned.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of the Reaper of Cania. He is known in the gods' tongue as Hecugoth the Abandoned. You recently used this knowledge to command him to let the Githzerai Pilgrims return to their home plane of Limbo.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of the Reaper of Cania. He is known in the gods' tongue as Hecugoth the Abandoned. You recently used this knowledge to command him to allow the Spirits of the Dead to pass through the Gates and haunt the Land of the Living.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of the Reaper of Cania. He is known in the gods' tongue as Hecugoth the Abandoned. You recently used this knowledge to command him to loose the Devils of Cania upon the unsuspecting planes.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of the Reaper of Cania. He is known in the gods' tongue as Hecugoth the Abandoned. You recently used it to command him to let you return home to Waterdeep to take your vengeance on the arch-devil Mephistopheles.

Having paid the Knower's price, you have learned the True Name of your henchman Valen. He is known in the gods' tongue as Oeskathine the Demonwrestler.
Empowered by this knowledge, you recently freed him from his demonic taint.

This hastily scrawled note bears Mephistopheles' now-familiar script:
"I am about to make my move and lay claim to Toril. Perhaps the Tanar'ri have caught wind of this for I have just received word that they are launching an assault near where I have stationed you. Stray catapult fire from the battle has already melted through the ice and freed one of my treacherous generals. Make your way to the prison and fend the Tanar'ri off at all costs. The last thing I need is some fool demon getting his paws on my Knower of Names. Serve me well and I may give you lordship over Waterdeep once it is mine..."
It appears that this particular front of the Blood War was opened just before he left for your homeworld, Toril.
Tendrils of magic bar your way. Beyond them you can hear a woman's sobs. Her voice, hollow and cold, echoes off the icy walls of her self-imposed prison.
Dark as a gathering storm, something about Aribeth's armor fills you with dread.
Aribeth's lovingly polished armor gleams in the dim light, keeping the darkness of the place at bay.
Ferron, leader of the rebel golems, is dead.
Aghaaz, leader of the Maker's golems, is dead.
A horrible creature, its flesh is sickly and yellow, covered with warts and oozing sores. Its long, filthy hair resembles rotting seaweed.

Aptly called a "landshark," the bulette is a terrifying predator that lives only to eat.

Troglodytes are cave-dwelling reptilian humanoids who take pleasure in fighting battles and in eating the bodies of their dead foes. While not very bright, trogs are known for their ferocity, cunning, and horrific stench.

When a Troglodyte is angry or frightened it secretes an oily, musk like chemical that nearly every form of animal life finds offensive.
All creatures (except Troglodytes) within 30 ft must succeed at a Fortitude save (DC 13) or be overcome with nausea. This lasts for 10 rounds and deals 1d6 points of temporary Strength damage.
A Sea Hag's appearance is so revolting that those setting eyes upon the Hag must make a Fortitude save (DC 11) or temporarily lose 2d8 points of strength.

A dire gaze can be cast upon any single creature within 30 feet. The target must succeed at a Fortitude save (DC 11). Creatures who fail lose 5 points from both strength and constitution and also have a 25% chance of losing 5 points from all ability scores due to fright.

(PRESTIGE CLASS) Worshipers of the Orc deity Gruumsh that have put out their own right eye in a bloody and painful ritual. These living martyrs to Gruumsh are some of the toughest orcs and half-orcs in the world. The eye of Gruumsh is a true prestige class in the sense that all orcs respect those who achieve it. Barbarians gain the most value from this prestige class, since it encourages raging as a fighting style
- Hit Die: d12 - Proficiencies: Simple and Martial Weapons, Light, and Medium Armor Proficiency, Shields - Skill Points: 2 + Int Modifier.
REQUIREMENTS:
Alignment: Chaotic evil, choatic neutral, or neutral evil. Race: Half-Orc or Orc Feats: Exotic Weapon Proficiency (Double Axe), Weapon Focus (Double Axe). Base Attack Bonus: +6
ABILITIES:
Level 1: Blind-Fight. Command the Horde Rage 1/day. 2. Swing Blindly - The character's rage's become more powerful granting a +4 strength bonus, while also suffering a -4 armor bonus while raging. 3: Ritual Scarring - Through frequent disfiguration of his own skin, the eye of Gruumsh gains a +1 natural armor bonus. 4: Blinding Spittle - The character can spit their stomach acid into a target's eyes 2/day. Rage 2/day. 5: Blindsight - The character gains blindsight in a 5 foot radius. 6: Ritual Scarring - The eye of Gruumsh's natural armor bonus increases to +2. 7: Blinding Spittle 4/day. 8: Blindsight 10 foot radius. Rage 3/day. 9: Ritual Scarring - The eye of Gruumsh's natural armor bonus increases to +3. 10: Sight of Gruumsh - The character gains a +2 morale bonus on all saving throws.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Eye of Gruumsh level 4. Specifics: At 4th level, an Eye of Gruumsh can launch blinding spittle at any opponent within 20 feet. Using a ranged touch attack (at a -4 penalty), he spits his stomach acid into the target's eyes. An opponent who fails a Reflex save (DC 10 + eye of Gruumsh level + eye of Gruumsh's Constitution bonus) is blinded until he or she can rinse away the spittle. This attack has no effect on creatures that don't have eyes or don't depend on vision. Blinding spittle is usable 2/day at 4th level and 4/day at 7th level. Use: Combat Mode.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Eye of Gruumsh level 1. Specifics: At 1st level, the Eye of Gruumsh may grant a +2 morale bonus on Will saving throws to any nongood orcs or half-orcs with Hit Dice lower than his character level within 30 feet. The effect lasts for 1 hour per eye of Gruumsh level. Use: Combat Mode.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Eye of Gruumsh level 2. Specifics: At 2nd level, the Eye of Gruumsh's rage ability becomes more powerful at the cost of lower defenses. The character gains an additional +4 bonus to his strength score while raging, while his armor class penalty increases to -4. Use: Combat Mode.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Eye of Gruumsh level 3. Specifics: Through frequent disfiguration of his own skin, the eye of Gruumsh gains a +1 natural armor bonus at 3rd level. This bonus increases by +1 for every three eye of Gruumsh levels gained thereafter. Use: Automatic.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Eye of Gruumsh level 5. Specifics: At 5th level, the Eye of Gruumsh gains blindsight in a 5 foot radius. Using hearing the eye of Gruumsh maneuvers and fights as well as a sighted creature. Invisibility and darkness are irrelevant within this range. The eye of Gruumsh does not need to make Spot or Listen checks to notice creatures within range of his blindsight ability. Use: Automatic.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Eye of Gruumsh level 8. Specifics: At 8th level, the Eye of Gruumsh gains blindsight in a 10 foot radius. Using hearing the eye of Gruumsh maneuvers and fights as well as a sighted creature. Invisibility and darkness are irrelevant within this range. The eye of Gruumsh does not need to make Spot or Listen checks to notice creatures within range of his blindsight ability. Use: Automatic.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Eye of Gruumsh level 10. Specifics: At 10th level, the Eye of Gruumsh sees the moment of his own death through his missing eye. This foreknowledge gives him a +2 morale bonus on all saving throws from then on. Use: Automatic.

Type of Feat: General Prerequisite: None. Specifics: Using nonvisual senses, such as sensitivity to vibrations, scent, acute hearing, or echolocation, the creature maneuvers and fights as well as a sighted creature. Invisibility and darkness are irrelevant. The creature usually does not need to make Spot or Listen checks to notice creatures within range of its blindsight ability. Use: Automatic.

(PRESTIGE CLASS) Shou disciples are martial artists who have studied or observed the monks of Kara-Tur and seek to emulate their style. Focusing more on the martial aspects of a monk's training, they sacrifice the enlightenment and supernatural abilities of the true ascetic. Shou disciples fight with martial weapons and often wear armor, instantly marking them as different from monks.
- Hit Die: d10 - Proficiencies: Martial and Monk Weapons, Light Armor Proficiency. - Skill Points: 2 + Int Modifier.
REQUIREMENTS:
Feats: Dodge, Improved Unarmed Strike, Weapon Focus (Unarmed Strike) Base Attack Bonus: +3 Skills: Tumble 4 ranks Base Reflex Save: +2
ABILITIES:
Level 1: Shou Disciple Dodge Bonus +1 (replaces the normal +1 dodge feat bonus). Unarmed Strike - The character deals 1d6 of unarmed damage. A Shou disciple with levels in the monk class will use the better of the two damage ranges, or the unarmed damage calculated by combining his Shou disciple and monk levels and using the unarmed damage of a monk of the resulting level if it produces a better result. Wearing light armor does not interfere with any of the Shou disciple's class abilities, but shields and medium or heavy armor do. 2: Unarmed Strike - The character deals 1d8 of unarmed damage. Shou Disciple Dodge Bonus +2 Bonus Feat - Chosen from the following list if the prerequisites are met: Deflect Arrows, Expertise, Improved Initiative, Improved Knockdown, Mobility, Power Attack, Spring Attack, Weapon Finesse and Weapon Specialization. 3: Unarmed Strike - The character deals 1d10 of unarmed damage. Martial Flurry (light) - The character gains the ability to use any light melee weapon for his flurry of blows. 4: Shou Disciple Dodge Bonus +3 Bonus Feat - Chosen from the following list if the prerequisites are met: Deflect Arrows, Expertise, Improved Initiative, Improved Knockdown, Mobility, Power Attack, Spring Attack, Weapon Finesse and Weapon Specialization. 5: Unarmed Strike - The character deals 2d6 of unarmed damage. Martial Flurry (any) - The character gains the ability to use any melee weapon for his flurry of blows.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Shou Disciple level 2. Specifics: Shou disciples are highly trained at dodging blows, giving the Shou disciple a +2 dodge bonus for his Dodge feat at 2nd level . A condition that makes the Shou disciple lose his Dexiterity bonus to armor class also makes him lose this dodge bonus. Use: Automatic.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Shou Disciple level 4. Specifics: Shou disciples are highly trained at dodging blows, giving the Shou disciple a +3 dodge bonus for his Dodge feat at 4th level . A condition that makes the Shou disciple lose his Dexiterity bonus to armor class also makes him lose this dodge bonus. Use: Automatic.

Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Shou Disciple level 3. Specifics: At 3rd level, a Shou disciple gains the ability to use any light melee weapon for his flurry of blows, not just Kamas. Use: Combat Mode.
Type of Feat: Class Prerequisite: Shou Disciple level 5. Specifics: At 5th level, a Shou disciple may use any melee weapon for his flurry of blows. Use: Combat Mode.
You are too large to equip that item.
This three-tined variation of a spear is a favored weapon of some undersea humanoids.

Reaching anywhere from 9 to 13 feet long, the Mako is one of the most terrifying hunters of the sea. Renowned for its speed and ability to really freak the heck out of anyone who thought it was a good idea to go swimming even after that old fisherman guy said that was a bad idea.

A relentless and cold killer whose unusual head shape allows for greater maneuverability in close quarters. Its ability to detect prey by smell is nearly ten times as sensitive as its shark brothers and thus makes a point showing off in front of all the girl sharks.

This extremely rare type of shark is distinctive for its long beak that protrudes out over its vicious jaws. Most adventurers when sighting a Goblin Shark for the first time are stunned by how deeply weird it looks and usually succumb to rows of pointed teeth soon after.

Highly intelligent coastal birds that have learned to co-exist with civilization in a scavenger role. Known for their distinctive squawks, white to gray coloring with black markings and distinct lack of toilette training.
Sometimes referred to as sea devils, sahuagin are marine predators that are superb underwater fighters as well as known for their midnight raids on the surface.
This amorphous creature resembles a harmless puddle of water.
This amorphous creature resembles a dark yellow amoeba.
Seaweed still clings to the salt-bleached wood.
Bubbles stream upwards from a small fissure in the sea floor. Whether they are a product of geothermal activity or some form of life that lurks below, you cannot tell.
A small candle floats on a driftwood plank.
Seashells and colored sands have been mixed in with the candlewax.
You wonder what desperate sea battle caused this treasure chest to be cast overboard, still unopened.
A hidden chest rises from the sands...
This is one of a variety of shells found in and around coastal regions.
A small school of fish darts about, seemingly oblivious to your presence.
This starfish has one more arm than you were expecting.
This shrine seems to be for the worship of some sort of aquatic god.
Skeletal remains adorn this barnacle-encrusted shrine.
You gaze at your reflection in the puddle. You look pretty good today, all things considered.
The clamshell that forms the back of this simple chair is bigger than any you've ever seen.
The Jolly Roger grimaces at you from this tattered pennant.
This salt-stiffened pennant bears the parting waves of the sea goddess, Umberlee.
The parrot eyes you warily, stepping back and forth along its perch.
The kelp sways gently in the ocean current.
This fishing net has been strung out to dry.
This egg is large and heavy. You wonder what manner of creature lies dead or dormant within its shell.
A pair of brightly colored eggs rests in a nest of dried palm fronds.
This nest of palm fronds seems like it hasn't been occupied in a while.
This hempen rope has been carefully coiled to ensure it doesn't get tangled with future use.
Planking scraps protrude from this coil of hempen rope, clearly intended for some future use.
This simple raft is constructed of scrap logs and improvised ropes. It seems sturdy enough.
This simple raft was constructed of scrap logs and improvised ropes. It seemed sturdy enough until its encounter with this rock.
Barnacles encrust this weathered throne. The bones of its last occupant still call it home.
The skeleton of a small creature, probably a dwarf, sways in the breeze.
You don't quite recognize the creature depicted by this barnacle-encrusted statue but it's clearly aquatic in nature. The stone is old and deeply weathered.
Fossilized sea life lends some maritime charm to this beautiful marble table.
This small clump of fungus thrives in its dank surroundings.
Barnacles cling to these weathered stones.
Small and made of rock slabs; a bed that only a dwarf could love.
A small bench made of smooth rock.
This carved rock table is extremely smooth and polished.
This smooth chair has been carved out of solid rock slabs.
Base Damage: 1d8 Base Critical Threat: x2 Base Damage Type: Piercing Weapon Size: Large Feats Required: Martial
